elements.content: The design and syntheses of porphyrin-based ligands are attractive for creating coordination assemblies with novel structures and intriguing properties. In this work, we designed and synthesized a novel porphyrin-based ligand 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4,4′-dipyridylaminophenylene)porphyrin (TDPAP, H2L) by the introduction of four peripheral 4,4′-dipyridylamine moieties to a porphyrin platform. Starting from this novel ligand, the protonated form of the ligand H4LCl2·2CH3OH­·2H2O (1) and four coordination polymers [Mn(III)Mn(II)LCl3­(DMF)] n (2), [Cu4L(CH3COO)5­(HCOO)­(CH3COOH)­(H2O)3] n ­·nCH3COOH­·nH2O (3), [Zn3L(CH3COO)4] n (4), and [Cd2H2L­(CH3COO)4] n ­·nDMF­·nCH3COOH­·2nH2O (5) were synthesized. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that a rich structural diversity was observed for these compounds due to the coordination of the multiple peripheral pyridines as well as the porphyrin core. 1 displays a hydrogen bonded one-dimensional (1D) structure composed of [(H2O)2Cl2]2– moieties. Complex 2 shows interpenetrated two-dimensional (2D) coordination networks, which are further linked by π···π stacking interactions to afford a three-dimensional (3D) structure. 3 shows a 2D sheet composed of 50- and 70-membered metallomacrocycles. In complex 4, 1D zigzag coordination chains were generated and further linked to form a 2D structure. Complex 5 has a stairlike 2D structure formed by the linkage of 1D coordination chains through the bridging of binuclear [Cd2(CO2)4] subunits. In these compounds, TDPAP shows a unique coordination behavior. It may bind 4–7 metal centers, and it demonstrates conformational flexibility and the ability to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds and π···π interactions, which contribute to the formation of novel supramolecular structures. On the basis of the novel structures, the solid state emissions of the compounds were also investigated.

elements.content: A novel porphyrin ligand 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4,4′-dipyridylaminophenylene)porphyrin (TDPAP) containing four 4,4′-dipyridylamine moieties was developed and coordinated with Mn(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) to afford coordination polymers with a rich structural diversity by the coordination of TDPAP with four, five, six, or even seven metal centers both at the porphyrin core and the peripheral pyridyl moieties.

elements.content: Supramolecular coordination assemblies of porphyrin-based ligands have attracted widespread interest. The porphyrin macrocycle provides a rather rigid square planar building block. The porphyrin core may coordinate with a metal ion, with the axial positions left for further coordination. In addition, various coordinating moieties can be introduced to the porphyrin peripheral positions. These diverse designing elements can be employed to develop desired coordination networks with diverse structures and intriguing properties with potential applications in various areas, such as hydrogen storage, molecular sorption and sensing, photonics, and heterogeneous catalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Supramolecular coordination assemblies of porphyrin-based ligands have attracted widespread interest. The porphyrin macrocycle provides a rather rigid square planar building block. The porphyrin core may coordinate with a metal ion, with the axial positions left for further coordination. In addition, various coordinating moieties can be introduced to the porphyrin peripheral positions. These diverse designing elements can be employed to develop desired coordination networks with diverse structures and intriguing properties with potential applications in various areas, such as hydrogen storage, molecular sorption and sensing, photonics, and heterogeneous catalysis.

elements.content: Pyridine is a versatile coordinating moiety, and four pyridyl groups were introduced to a porphyrin framework to afford a typical porphyrin-based ligand, tetrakis(4-pyridyl) porphyrin (TPyP, Scheme ), which has been extensively used to construct coordination polymers by the coordination of the porphyrin core and the peripheral pyridines. On the other hand, 4,4′-dipyridylamine (4,4′-dpa) contains two pyridines, which may bridge two metal centers. In recent years, it has been demonstrated to be promising for the construction of diverse coordination polymers. In this respect, we have utilized 4,4′-dpa to develop novel polydentate ligands (Scheme a–c) and construct coordination polymers of d10 metals with interesting structures and tunable luminescent properties.
elements.clean_text: Pyridine is a versatile coordinating moiety, and four pyridyl groups were introduced to a porphyrin framework to afford a typical porphyrin-based ligand, tetrakis(4-pyridyl) porphyrin (TPyP, Scheme ), which has been extensively used to construct coordination polymers by the coordination of the porphyrin core and the peripheral pyridines. On the other hand, 4,4'-dipyridylamine (4,4'-dpa) contains two pyridines, which may bridge two metal centers. In recent years, it has been demonstrated to be promising for the construction of diverse coordination polymers. In this respect, we have utilized 4,4'-dpa to develop novel polydentate ligands (Scheme a-c) and construct coordination polymers of d10 metals with interesting structures and tunable luminescent properties.

elements.clean_text: 1  Chemical Structures of Typical 4,4'-dpa Derived Ligands (a-c), TPyP (d), and TDPAP (e)

elements.content: In this work, we further combined the porphyrin framework with 4,4′-dpa to design a novel ligand 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4,4′-dipyridylaminophenylene)porphyrin (TDPAP, Scheme e), which contains eight peripheral pyridines and thus may coordinate with a maximum of nine metal centers. And the 4,4’-dipyridylaminophenylene moieties may rotate around the porphyrin framework, which may result in good conformational flexibility of the ligand. Because of these structural features, TDPAP may coordinate with various metals to afford coordination assemblies with a rich structural diversity. Thus, we synthesized TDPAP and its coordination polymers with Mn(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II). Single crystals of the protonated ligand H4LCl2·2CH3OH·2H2O (1), and the coordination polymers, [Mn(III)Mn(II)­LCl3(DMF)] n (2), [Cu4L(CH3COO)5­(HCOO)­(CH3COOH)­(H2O)3] n ­·nCH3COOH­·nH2O (3), [Zn3L(CH3COO)4] n (4), and [Cd2H2L­(CH3COO)4] n ­·nDMF­·nCH3COOH­·2nH2O (5) were successfully obtained and structurally characterized. These compounds exhibit a rich structural diversity, including a hydrogen-bonded one-dimensional (1D) supramolecular structure composed of [(H2O)2Cl2]2– moieties, a three-dimensional (3D) structure formed by the π···π stacking interactions between interpenetrated two-dimensional (2D) networks, a 2D structure with large cavities composed of 50- and 70-membered metallomacrocycles, a complicated 2D structure linked by zigzag chains, and a stairlike 2D structure containing binuclear [Cd2(CO2)4] subunits. The solid state emission properties were also measured and discussed based on the structural results.

elements.content:
All chemicals of reagent grade quality were used as received from commercial sources without further purification.

Physical Measurements

1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE spectrometer (400 MHz). HRMS were performed using a Waters LCT Premier XE spectrometer. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the region of 400–4000 cm–1 on a Thermo Electron Avatar 380 FT-IR instrument (KBr Discs). Elemental analyses were carried out with an Elmentar Vario EL-III analyzer. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary 100 spectrophotometer, and solid state emission measurements were performed on a Varian Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. The excitation spectra of the compounds show the maximum excitation wavelengths within the range of 477–480 nm (), and the excitation wavelength was fixed at 480 nm for the sake of convenience. The cyclic voltammograms were obtained with a Versastat II electrochemical workstation (Princeton Applied Research). TGA curves were measured using a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 thermogravimetric analyzer in a flowing of nitrogen atmosphere at the rate of 100 mL·min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns () were collected on a D/max 2550VB/PC powder X-ray diffractometer at 293 K using Cu Kα radiation with the scan rate of 3°/min.

The excitation spectra of the compounds show the maximum excitation wavelengths within the range of 477-480 nm (), and the excitation wavelength was fixed at 480 nm for the sake of convenience. TGA curves were measured using a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 thermogravimetric analyzer in a flowing of nitrogen atmosphere at the rate of 100 mL⋅min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns () were collected on a D/max 2550VB/PC powder X-ray diffractometer at 293 K using Cu Kα radiation with the scan rate of 3°/min.

elements.content: 4,4′-Dipyridylamine (4.00 g, 23.4 mmol), 4-bromobenzaldehyde (12.80 g, 70.0 mmol), anhydrous potassium carbonate (6.40 g, 46.8 mmol), cupric sulfate (720 mg, 4.4 mmol), 18-crown-6 (240 mg, 1.0 mmol), and biphenyl ether (50 mL) were added to a three-necked flask and heated at 180 °C under N2 for 2 days. After the reaction mixture was cooled, dichloromethane and methanol were added to dissolve the solid, and then the solution was filtered and the filtrate was collected. After removal of the solvent, the residue was purified on a silica gel column to afford a yellowish solid (3.86 g, yield 81% based on 4,4′-dipyridylamine). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 9.99 (s, 1H, CHO), 8.50 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 4H, pyridyl-H), 7.91 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H, phenylene-H), 7.30 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H, phenylene-H), 7.00 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 4H, pyridyl-H). HRMS: obsd 276.1132, calcd for C17H14N3O1 ([M + H]+): 276.1137.

X-ray Crystallography

X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker-AXS APEX diffractometer utilizing Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full matrix least-squares technique. Anisotropic thermal parameters were applied to all non-hydrogen atoms. All of the hydrogen atoms in these structures are located from the differential electron density map and constrained to the ideal positions in the refinement procedure. All calculations were performed using the SHELX-97 software package. Crystal data and experimental details for the crystals are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table S1 (see the ).

4-(4,4′-Dipyridylamino)benzaldehyde is the key intermediate for the preparation of TDPAP. It was prepared in a moderate yield from an Ullmann condensation reaction of 4,4′-dipyridylamine with 4-bromobenzaldehyde at 180 °C in diphenyl ether, using cupric sulfate, 18-crown-6 and K2CO3 as catalysts and the base, respectively. 4-Bromobenzaldehyde was used in excess to completely convert 4,4′-dpa, which was clearly observed by thin layer chromatography (TLC). Thus, the aldehyde was obtained in a satisfactory yield of 81%. Then, TDPAP was prepared by the condensation of pyrrole with the aldehyde in refluxing propionic acid. For such porphyrin syntheses reactions, the porphyrin product usually could be precipitated by the addition of MeOH. Unfortunately, TDPAP could not be effectively precipitated in this way, which may be related to the good solubility of TDPAP in methanol due to the presence of eight pyridyl moieties in the molecule. To overcome this problem, the propionic acid was carefully neutralized with an aqueous NaOH solution, and the product was extracted by dichloromethane. After the solvent was removed, the residue was purified on a silica gel column to afford a purple solid of TDPAP in a moderate yield. The UV–vis absorption spectrum of TDPAP showed a typical porphyrin Soret band at 416 nm and four Q bands at 515, 550, 591, and 648 nm, respectively (). The electrochemical behavior of TDPAP was studied by cyclic voltammetry (), which revealed a half-wave oxidation potential E 1/2 of 1.04 V, close to that of tetraphenylporphyrin (TPP), indicating that the electronic effect of the 4,4′-dipyridylamino moieties are rather weak.

Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Characterization

4-(4,4'-Dipyridylamino)benzaldehyde is the key intermediate for the preparation of TDPAP. It was prepared in a moderate yield from an Ullmann condensation reaction of 4,4'-dipyridylamine with 4-bromobenzaldehyde at 180 °C in diphenyl ether, using cupric sulfate, 18-crown-6 and K2CO3 as catalysts and the base, respectively. 4-Bromobenzaldehyde was used in excess to completely convert 4,4'-dpa, which was clearly observed by thin layer chromatography (TLC). Thus, the aldehyde was obtained in a satisfactory yield of 81%. Then, TDPAP was prepared by the condensation of pyrrole with the aldehyde in refluxing propionic acid. For such porphyrin syntheses reactions, the porphyrin product usually could be precipitated by the addition of MeOH. Unfortunately, TDPAP could not be effectively precipitated in this way, which may be related to the good solubility of TDPAP in methanol due to the presence of eight pyridyl moieties in the molecule. To overcome this problem, the propionic acid was carefully neutralized with an aqueous NaOH solution, and the product was extracted by dichloromethane. After the solvent was removed, the residue was purified on a silica gel column to afford a purple solid of TDPAP in a moderate yield. The UV-vis absorption spectrum of TDPAP showed a typical porphyrin Soret band at 416 nm and four Q bands at 515, 550, 591, and 648 nm, respectively (). The electrochemical behavior of TDPAP was studied by cyclic voltammetry (), which revealed a half-wave oxidation potential E 1/2 of 1.04 V, close to that of tetraphenylporphyrin (TPP), indicating that the electronic effect of the 4,4'-dipyridylamino moieties are rather weak.

elements.content: With this novel ligand in hand, we tried to synthesize the coordination polymers by solvothermal reactions in DMF, DMSO, MeOH, and H2O. But too much precipitate was generated immediately after the addition of the metal salts to the ligand solutions due to the presence of the multiple pyridine moieties in the molecule, and only fine powders were generated except that the single crystals of [Mn(III)Mn(II)LCl3(DMF)] n (2) were fortunately obtained in this way. Then, with the purpose to retard the coordination reactions, eliminate the precipitates, and thus obtain the single crystals, a certain amount of acetic acid was added before the addition of the metal salts, and thus single crystals of the coordination polymers may be slowly generated in this way. As expected, this method worked very well, and single crystals of the Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) complexes (3–5) were successfully obtained.

Then, with the purpose to retard the coordination reactions, eliminate the precipitates, and thus obtain the single crystals, a certain amount of acetic acid was added before the addition of the metal salts, and thus single crystals of the coordination polymers may be slowly generated in this way. As expected, this method worked very well, and single crystals of the Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) complexes (3-5) were successfully obtained.

elements.content: The crystal of 1 contains a centrosymmetric diprotonated ligand [H4L]2+ (Figure ), two chloride, two methanol, and two water molecules. Because of the steric hindrance effect, the phenylene rings are tilted from the porphyrin framework with dihedral angles of 66.8(5) and 64.0(2)°, respectively. Two chlorides and two lattice waters are hydrogen bonded to form a [(H2O)2Cl2]2– moiety, which was further linked to two pyridinium moieties from two diprotonated ligands. The Cl···H distances lie within the range of 2.25–2.54 Å, and the N–H···Cl and O–H···Cl angles are 167° and 166°, respectively. By the linkage of these hydrogen bonds, a 1D supramolecular structure is formed (Figure ).

elements.content: Complex 2 was obtained from the reaction of TDPAP with MnCl2 in DMF and CH3CN, and the structure is shown in Figure . It consists of two kinds of crystallographically independent Mn atoms. Mn1 coordinates with four pyrrolyl nitrogens in the porphyrin core and the axial positions are occupied by a Cl– and an O atom from a DMF ligand (Figure a). Mn2 coordinates with four peripheral pyridyl nitrogens from four TDPAP ligands in addition to two Cl– anions at the axial positions. Thus, both Mn1 and Mn2 atoms have octahedral coordination geometries. Mn1–N and Mn2–N distances lie in the ranges of 2.001(6)–2.030(4) Å and 2.314(5)–2.333(4) Å, respectively, indicating that Mn1 and Mn2 are trivalent and divalent, respectively. The three positive charges of Mn1 are balanced by the dianionic porphyrin core and the chloro ligand. Finally, each Mn2 atom links four TDPAP ligands, and each TDPAP ligand links four Mn2 atoms to afford a 2D network composed of large cavities of 50-membered metallomacrocycles. The Mn1 and Mn2 atoms can be regarded as four-connecting nodes. Thus, the topology of the network can be described as a simple uninodal four-connected 44 -sql net. The 2D network is undulated (Figure c) and interpenetrated by another such network (Figure b). It is noteworthy that the π···π stacking interactions are observed between the pyridyl rings from neighboring layers, with the dihedral angles of 7.9(8)°, the centroid···centroid distances of 4.060(6) Å, and the closest interplane C···C distances of 3.535(6) Å. By the linkage of these π···π interactions, a 3D structure is formed (Figure c).

elements.content: Manganese-TPyP coordination networks have been reported, with the Mn ion in the porphyrin core axially coordinated with two pyridyl nitrogens from neighboring TPyP ligands. In the crystal of 2, the Mn(III) atom in the porphyrin core was not coordinated with the pyridyl nitrogens of neighboring TDPAP ligands, which may be related to the steric hindrance associated with the bulky 4,4′-dpa moieties.

elements.content: Single crystals of complex 3 were obtained from the reaction of Cu(OAc)2 with TDPAP in a mixture of DMF, HOAc, and H2O. Cu1 is coordinated in the porphyrin core of TDPAP with a square-planar coordination environment (Figure a), and TDPAP further utilizes its six peripheral pyridyl nitrogens to coordinate with six Cu2+ ions, and four of them are crystallographically independent. Among them, Cu2 is coordinated with two pyridyl nitrogens, two acetates, and an aqua ligand, affording a pseudosquare pyramidal environment, with a long axial Cu···O (aqua) bond length of 2.452(5) Å. The coordination bond lengths in the basal plane lie in the range of 1.950(7)–2.007(5) Å. Cu3 is octahedrally coordinated with two pyridyl nitrogens, two formates, and two axial aqua ligands, with long Cu···O (aqua) bond lengths of 2.853(5) Å. The coordination bond lengths in the equatorial plane lie in the range of 1.981(5)–1.988(5) Å. The formate observed in the crystal may originate from the decomposition of DMF at the high temperature, or the impurity contained in the acetic acid reagent. Cu4 is tetracoordinated with two pyridyl nitrogens and two acetates, with the Cu–N and Cu–O bond lengths varying in the range of 1.946(5)–1.999(5) Å. And Cu5 is octahedrally coordinated with two pyridyl nitrogens and two acetates, in addition to axially coordinated acetic acid and aqua ligands with long Cu···O axial bond lengths of 2.504(6) and 2.656(6) Å. For the Cu(II) atoms, the coordination bonds in the equatorial or the basal planes lie within the normal ranges for Cu–N and Cu–O lengths in similar complexes. The occurrence of long axial Cu···O bonds and even the absence of axial ligands may be related to the Jahn–Teller effect associated with the d9 electronic configuration of Cu2+.

elements.content: Complex 4 was obtained from the reaction of TDPAP with Zn(OAc)2 in HOAc, DMF, and MeOH. Three crystallographically independent Zn(II) atoms are observed. Zn1 coordinates in the porphyrin core and one of the axial positions is coordinated to one pyridyl nitrogen from a neighboring ligand to form a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry. Zn2 and Zn3 are respectively coordinated with two pyridyl nitrogens from two TDPAP ligands, in addition to two O atoms from two acetates to afford tetrahedral coordination environments. The Zn–N and Zn–O bond lengths lie in the ranges of 2.018(5)–2.159(4) Å and 1.927(5)–2.034(8) Å, respectively. TDPAP utilizes one of its pyridyl nitrogen atoms to coordinate with Zn1A from a neighboring porphyrin core to afford a 1D zigzag chain (Figure b), and the other four pyridyl nitrogen atoms are coordinated with Zn2, Zn2B, Zn3, and Zn3C to construct a 2D network (Figure c). These results indicate that TDPAP may utilize more than four peripheral coordinating atoms to coordinate with Zn2+ for constructing complicated supramolecular coordination assemblies with structures totally different from those constructed from the tetrapyridyl TPyP ligand.

elements.content: In the crystal of complex 5, each Cd(II) is seven-coordinated to five O atoms from three acetates, and two N atoms from two TDPAP ligands. Interestingly, four acetates connect two Cd(II) cations to afford a binuclear [Cd2(CO2)4] subunit (Figure a), where two of the acetates adopt the μ2-chelating-bridging mode, and the other two adopt the chelating mode. The Cd–N and Cd–O bond lengths lie within the normal ranges of 2.324(6)–2.351(7) Å, and 2.222(11)–2.547(9) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Each TDPAP ligand utilizes four pyridyl nitrogens to coordinate with four Cd(II) atoms, thus forming 1D ladder-like chains, which are further linked by the bridging acetates to form a 2D network with an interesting stair-like structure containing [Cd2(CO2)4] subunits (Figure ). Interestingly, the 2D network contains large cavities composed of 50-membered metallomacrocycles. Topologically, the Cd2(CO2)4 moieties can be simplified as four-connected cluster nodes, and thus the topology of 5 can be regarded as a known uninodal four-connected 44-sql net, similar to that of complex 2.

Interestingly, the 2D network contains large cavities composed of 50-membered metallomacrocycles. Topologically, the Cd2(CO2)4 moieties can be simplified as four-connected cluster nodes, and thus the topology of 5 can be regarded as a known uninodal four-connected 44-sql net, similar to that of complex 2.

elements.content: In complex 5, the porphyrin core remains noncoordinated to Cd2+, which may be related to the too large radius of Cd2+ to fit in the porphyrin core. In spite of this, it is known that Cd2+ may coordinate with porphyrin, by locating above the porphyrin core. Thus, it may be anticipated that novel Cd2+ complexes of TDPAP with Cd2+ coordinated to the porphyrin core may be obtained by using different Cd2+ salts under different reaction conditions, which is under further research in our group.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses of the complexes were performed by heating the samples from 40 to 800 °C under N2 (). The loss of the lattice solvents was observed from the temperature of 50 °C, and the decomposition of the complex frameworks occurred at 470, 220, 506, and 473 °C for compounds 2, 3, 4, and 5, respectively, indicative of the moderate to good thermal stability of the coordination frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analyses of the complexes were performed by heating the samples from 40 to 800 °C under N2 (). The loss of the lattice solvents was observed from the temperature of 50 °C, and the decomposition of the complex frameworks occurred at 470, 220, 506, and 473 °C for compounds 2, 3, 4, and 5, respectively, indicative of the moderate to good thermal stability of the coordination frameworks.

elements.content: As discussed above, interesting and diverse coordination structures were observed for complexes 2–5, with the TDPAP ligand coordinated in different modes. As is described above, each TDPAP ligand has four peripheral 4,4′-dpa moieties and a porphyrin core composed of four pyrrolic nitrogens. Theoretically, it may coordinate to a maximum of nine metal centers, one in the center and eight at the peripheries. In this work, TDPAP displays four types of coordination modes, with each TDPAP ligand coordinated to four, five, six, or seven metal centers for complexes 5, 2, 4, and 3, respectively (Scheme ). In complex 5, four peripheral pyridyl nitrogens are coordinated, but the porphyrin core is metal-free. And the porphyrin core in complex 2 is coordinated in addition to the coordination of four peripheral pyridyl nitrogens. In comparison to complex 2, the coordination of additional peripheral nitrogen is observed in complex 4. Interestingly, one of the 4,4′-dpa moieties utilizes two N atoms for coordination. However, the coordination of only one N atom is observed for each of the remaining three dpa moieties. Furthermore, seven metal centers are coordinated to the TDPAP ligand in complex 3. In addition to the variation in the number of the coordinated metal centers, TDPAP also shows conformational flexibility, with the dihedral angles between the peripheral pyridines and the porphyrin core varying in a large range of 0.3–89.8°. Thus, a rich structural diversity was observed. Furthermore, the pyridyl rings may be involved in intermolecular π···π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonds, which result in novel supramolecular structures.

And the porphyrin core in complex 2 is coordinated in addition to the coordination of four peripheral pyridyl nitrogens. In comparison to complex 2, the coordination of additional peripheral nitrogen is observed in complex 4. Interestingly, one of the 4,4'-dpa moieties utilizes two N atoms for coordination. However, the coordination of only one N atom is observed for each of the remaining three dpa moieties. Furthermore, seven metal centers are coordinated to the TDPAP ligand in complex 3. In addition to the variation in the number of the coordinated metal centers, TDPAP also shows conformational flexibility, with the dihedral angles between the peripheral pyridines and the porphyrin core varying in a large range of 0.3-89.8°. elements.content: Porphyrin-based systems often present interesting structure-dependent photoluminescent properties, and thus we continued to investigate the emission spectra of TDPAP and compounds 1–5 in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). The free ligand TDPAP displays two medium-intensity emission peaks at 679 nm (singlet decay) and 726 nm (triplet decay) upon excitation at 480 nm. For compounds 2 and 3, no obvious emission was observed, which may be ascribed to the paramagnetic effect of the Mn(II), Mn(III), and Cu(II) centers. The emissions of compounds 1 and 5 are significantly weaker than that of the TDPAP ligand, which may be ascribed to the protonation of the ligand and the heavy-atom effect. For compound 4, Zn2+ is unsymmetrically coordinated at the axial positions, and it is displaced from the porphyrin framework. Thus, the symmetry and the aromaticity of the porphyrin macrocycle are decreased, resulting in the elevated HOMO–LUMO energy gap. Thus, a blue-shifted peak at 668 nm with weaker intensity was observed for 4. These results indicate that the emission behavior can be effectively modulated by the protonation and metal coordination.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

Porphyrin-based systems often present interesting structure-dependent photoluminescent properties, and thus we continued to investigate the emission spectra of TDPAP and compounds 1-5 in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). The free ligand TDPAP displays two medium-intensity emission peaks at 679 nm (singlet decay) and 726 nm (triplet decay) upon excitation at 480 nm. For compounds 2 and 3, no obvious emission was observed, which may be ascribed to the paramagnetic effect of the Mn(II), Mn(III), and Cu(II) centers. The emissions of compounds 1 and 5 are significantly weaker than that of the TDPAP ligand, which may be ascribed to the protonation of the ligand and the heavy-atom effect. For compound 4, Zn2+ is unsymmetrically coordinated at the axial positions, and it is displaced from the porphyrin framework. Thus, the symmetry and the aromaticity of the porphyrin macrocycle are decreased, resulting in the elevated HOMO-LUMO energy gap. Thus, a blue-shifted peak at 668 nm with weaker intensity was observed for 4. These results indicate that the emission behavior can be effectively modulated by the protonation and metal coordination.

elements.content: Porphyrin is a kind of functional and structural robust synthon for the design and construction of crystalline frameworks. In this work, a novel porphyrin-based ligand TDPAP (H2L) containing four peripheral 4,4′-dipyridylamine moieties was prepared and used to coordinate with Mn(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) to afford various complexes. In addition, the protonated ligand was also structurally characterized. The TDPAP ligand was demonstrated to coordinate with 4–7 metal centers, and the 4,4’-dipyridylaminophenylene moieties may rotate around the porphyrin framework, resulting in good conformational flexibility of TDPAP. Thus, a rich structural diversity was observed for the complexes. Furthermore, intermolecular π···π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonds involving the pyridyl rings contribute to the formation of novel supramolecular structures. The solid state emission measurements indicate that the emission behavior can be effectively modulated by the protonation and metal coordination effects. These results indicate that TDPAP is promising for the construction of metal coordination assemblies with novel structures and interesting properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Porphyrin is a kind of functional and structural robust synthon for the design and construction of crystalline frameworks. In this work, a novel porphyrin-based ligand TDPAP (H2L) containing four peripheral 4,4'-dipyridylamine moieties was prepared and used to coordinate with Mn(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) to afford various complexes. In addition, the protonated ligand was also structurally characterized. The TDPAP ligand was demonstrated to coordinate with 4-7 metal centers, and the 4,4'-dipyridylaminophenylene moieties may rotate around the porphyrin framework, resulting in good conformational flexibility of TDPAP. Thus, a rich structural diversity was observed for the complexes. Furthermore, intermolecular π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonds involving the pyridyl rings contribute to the formation of novel supramolecular structures. The solid state emission measurements indicate that the emission behavior can be effectively modulated by the protonation and metal coordination effects. These results indicate that TDPAP is promising for the construction of metal coordination assemblies with novel structures and interesting properties.

A mixture of TDPAP (2.60 mg, 0.002 mmol) and Cd(OAc)2⋅3H2O (4.60 mg, 0.020 mmol) in DMF, HOAc, and MeOH (4:9:4, 3.4 mL) was sealed in a 10 mL Teflon lined stainless steel vessel under autogenous pressure and heated to 150 °C for 90 h. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, brownish prismatic crystals of 5 suitable for X-ray diffraction analyses were obtained in the yield of ~52%. Anal. (%) calcd. for C97H85Cd2N17O13: C, 60.52; H, 4.45; N, 12.38. Found: C, 59.89; H, 4.51; N, 12.14. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3400(br), 2919(w), 1578(vs), 1495(s), 1403(m), 1384(w), 1338 (m), 1310(w), 1281(w), 1216(m), 1103(m), 1015(w), 991(w), 965(w), 812(s), 733(m), 622(m), 527(m), 466(m).

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses of the complexes were performed by heating the samples from 40 to 800 °C under N2 (). The loss of the lattice solvents was observed from the temperature of 50 °C, and the decomposition of the complex frameworks occurred at 470, 220, 506, and 473 °C for compounds 2, 3, 4, and 5, respectively, indicative of the moderate to good thermal stability of the coordination frameworks.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analyses of the complexes were performed by heating the samples from 40 to 800 °C under N2 (). The loss of the lattice solvents was observed from the temperature of 50 °C, and the decomposition of the complex frameworks occurred at 470, 220, 506, and 473 °C for compounds 2, 3, 4, and 5, respectively, indicative of the moderate to good thermal stability of the coordination frameworks.
